text.p: Here are the highlights from Swiss newspapers on Wednesday:
- Over 10,000 miners gathered to protest in Bonn against plans to reduce subsidies to the German coal industry.
- Albanian president Sali Berisha picked a new prime minister, Socialist Bashkim Fino, while rebels in Southern Albania consolidated their position.
- Russian leader Boris Yeltsin announced plans to restructure the government which involves reduces the number of deputy officials and the number of ministers.

- Swiss parliament has taken up the debate on the value-added tax. Swiss finance minister Kaspar Villiger underscores meanwhile that the tax must remain a general, broad tax and must be applied in a fair and equal manner.
- Cantonal governments of Geneva and Waadt plan to link University hospitals and medical schools via computer network.
- In Brussels, European Union transportation ministers, in response to pressure from Austria, may favour an "alpine clause" in negotiations on heavy vehicle transport.
- The Swiss economy shows signs of recovery according to GDP figures released on Tuesday. Swiss fourth quarter GDP was unchanged, following seven quarters of declining growth.
- The European Commission is pressing for immediate access for 40-tonne trucks in Switzerland. The Commission plans to meetings at the end of April with Swiss to finalise an agreement.
- An American, 41-year old Jeffrey Katz, has been named chief executive of SAirGroup's Swissair airline unit.
- The Canton of Zurich reports 19,322 break-ins in 1996, up eight percent and close to the record reported in 1983.
